choices.text:
### Human:
Explain origin of standard gauge for railways
### Assistant:

The term "standard" in the context of railways refers to a track with a fixed distance between the rails. The first standards were set by George Stephenson, who built the Liverpool and Manchester Railway (1825). He used cast iron plates as sleepers on stone blocks for the track bed; these provided some flexibility so that the line could cope with expansion due to heat or moisture without cracking.
The standard gauge of 4 ft 8 1⁄2 in was first introduced by Robert Stephenson, who built the Stockton and Darlington Railway (1825). He used cast iron plates as sleepers on stone blocks for the track bed; these provided some flexibility so that the line could cope with expansion due to heat or moisture without cracking.
The standard gauge of 4 ft 8 1⁄2 in was first introduced by Robert Stephenson, who built the Stockton and Darlington Railway (1825). He used cast iron plates as sleepers on stone blocks for the track bed; these provided some flexibility so that the line could cope with expansion due to heat or moisture without cracking.
